[[Saa]] represents the personification of wisdom or the god of wisdom in Ancient Egyptian Mythology.
 
[[Saa]] represents the personification of wisdom or the god of wisdom in Ancient Egyptian Mythology.
    −
=== Bible ===
+
=== Hebrew Bible & Judaism ===
 
In the [[Bible]], wisdom is represented by [[Solomon]], who asks God for wisdom in {{bibleref|2Chronicles|1}}. Much of the [[Book of Proverbs]], a book of wise sayings, is attributed to Solomon. In {{bibleref|Proverbs|1:7}} and {{bibleref|Proverbs|9:10}}, the fear of the [[LORD]] is called the beginning or foundation of wisdom while {{bibleref|Proverbs|8:13}} declares "To fear the Lord is to hate evil". In {{bibleref|Proverbs|1:20}}, there is also reference to wisdom personified in female form, "Wisdom calls aloud in the street, she raises her voice in the public squares." [[Adhan#Text|(Adan)]] Continuing in {{bibleref|Proverbs|8:22-31}}, this personified wisdom is described as being present with God before creation began and even taking part in creation itself, delighting especially in human beings.
 
In the [[Bible]], wisdom is represented by [[Solomon]], who asks God for wisdom in {{bibleref|2Chronicles|1}}. Much of the [[Book of Proverbs]], a book of wise sayings, is attributed to Solomon. In {{bibleref|Proverbs|1:7}} and {{bibleref|Proverbs|9:10}}, the fear of the [[LORD]] is called the beginning or foundation of wisdom while {{bibleref|Proverbs|8:13}} declares "To fear the Lord is to hate evil". In {{bibleref|Proverbs|1:20}}, there is also reference to wisdom personified in female form, "Wisdom calls aloud in the street, she raises her voice in the public squares." [[Adhan#Text|(Adan)]] Continuing in {{bibleref|Proverbs|8:22-31}}, this personified wisdom is described as being present with God before creation began and even taking part in creation itself, delighting especially in human beings.
